pros: People, benefits, great leave time
cons: Salary is often less than k-12 with similar experience.

pros: Benefits are paid for by OTC
cons: Not enough money for the amount of work

pros: Low pay, poor leadership of the center, inappropriate behavior, foul language, not a learning environment. Not sure where OTC found these folks to manage the center but it is poorly run and they are very immature.
cons: Internal audit needs to be done with this department.

review_title: Great Community College in Southwest Missouri
pros: Freedom to do your job. Support from colleagues. Support from department chairs. Questions you may have will be answered. Great graduation ceremony.
cons: Low end pay. Would be nice for an employee appreciation event to occur each year. No where to advance to except administration. Increase in pay depends upon years of service to the school, not education level.

pros: Flexible schedule that can change each semester. Casual environment.
cons: Lack of direction, many employees were irresponsible and under qualified, lots of drama

pros: Students are the best ever
cons: Administrative staff really is out of touch

pros: Student based services that support students through their program
cons: Confusion process changes Lack of communication between departments Additional job responsibilities not initially listed are added after the fact without compensation

pros: Benefits like health insurance, 401k, and a free clinic on campus.
cons: Healthy Leadership is severely lacking. So many policies in place that bottleneck the work that needs to get done. The compensation is horrible for the amount of work that gets put on you.

review_title: Pretty Good but Room for Improvement
pros: It is nice to have paid holidays, as well as two full weeks paid time off during winter break when there are no students in classes. We also have the opportunity to accrue paid sick-leave and paid vacation time to request/use whenever we would like. Everyone is typically pretty professional (with the exception of a few long-time employees), and there are a lot of great people that work here. There are a lot of opportunities for internal hires if you're looking for a new position within the company, or if you're looking to climb up the ladder.
cons: In my opinion, OTC does not pay their employees enough. They pay the going-rates I suppose, but it is still hard to make ends meet. They take care of their students and the community, but it would be nice for the employees to also be shown that they're of higher value. They also do not offer any over-time; you have to get a flat 40 hours a week (which is 9 hours a day Monday-Friday, but you have to take a mandatory 1 hour unpaid lunch each day so you only get paid for 8). There aren't a lot of raises offered or any available really, so if you're struggling financially then your only options are to find another job, or pick up a part-time job in your off-time and over extend yourself. More competitive pay would help a lot. We offer Associate's Degrees and Certificate opportunities, and advertise how much money you can make with just an Associate's or Certificate, but then most of the positions here require at least a Bachelor's Degree, and the pay is not competitive.

review_title: Too stressful for the amount of pay
job_title: Bookstore Sales Associate in Springfield, MO
pros: Getting to work between classes
cons: Some managers were friendly, some were not.

review_title: great work experience but low pay
job_title: Warehouse Worker in New York, NY
pros: very flexible scheduling, friendly work environment
cons: low pay and inconsistent hours

pros: Great coworkers, Schedule flexibility, Decent pay
cons: Days off (no income) when university is closed

pros: The managers at the bookstore are phenomenal. Great flexibility for college students. Easy-going workplace.
cons: If I had to point out a con, it would be that you start out as a seasonal hire and then you might get offered a full time year round position a couple weeks into working. Along with that, you do get paid every four weeks instead of the typical two week payments.

pros: Love this place. Everyone is focused on students and their success.
cons: None that I see now.

pros: It has a relaxed environment.
cons: Leadership is really bad and inconsistent.

review_title: Underpaid and a lot of politics.
pros: Employer pays 100% of health insurance for employees. Generous pto plan. Paid holiday days (including from Christmas Eve to Jan 2nd).
cons: Pay is low and often 1 person is asked to do the job of 3. No overtime is allowed. If you don't agree with the politics of upper management, you won't EVER get promoted or hired into another position.

review_title: Worst and Most Unethical Place I have ever worked
pros: The schedule is the only pro.
cons: This place is TOXIC from the bottom all the way to the chancellor. You would not believe how many things are swept under the rug and how people get ahead just to get a title here. There are policies in place for a reason, but OTC does not believe in enforcing them. I worked here for 12 years and it has been progressively getting worse. Look on casenet for further lawsuits against OTC. They even hide their name and change the name of the college in order to hide their issues from the public.

review_title: Great organization with a bright future
pros:
-Professional atmosphere
-Leadership promotes growth and innovation
-Generous benefits
-Employees care about students
-Culture of promoting from within
cons:
-Diverse student body but not reflected in faculty/administration yet
-Lack of mid-career-level positions
-Remote work policies will need to evolve with changing industry

pros:
The Speckman Tutoring and Learning Center (TLC) is the best work environment I have ever worked for. Amazing coworkers. Your supervisors treat you like a person first, not just an employee. Very big on teaching us excellent customer service skills, and always very helpful if you're not sure how to do something. They're big on helping you improve, not criticizing you, if you get something wrong.
Very flexible schedule.
cons: Difficult to get a full time position.

pros: Good place to work in town
cons: Cannot think of any at the moment

pros: great benefits and growing organization
cons: middle managers hoard information all the time.

review_title: They ask to much of their PT employees and turn a blind eye.  19.5 hours/week cap
pros: A lot of dedicated and passionate employees.
cons: Underpay and unequal treatment of PT employees compared to FT.

job_title: IT Help Desk Technician in Springfield, MO
pros: Flexible hours and a good working environment.
cons: The pay isn't great and they don't give you enough hours.

job_title: Vice President in Little Rock, AR
pros: Great place to work for small town
cons: Rural communities has a downside

pros: Good selection of classes to teach
cons: Sometimes difficult for classes to make if you are in a specialty area.

pros: Great staff, supportive, amazing HR team, great benefits and pay
cons: Some supervisors are not nice or good at their jobs and can be lazy and pass their work off to subordinates.

pros: flexible hours, nice people, good place to work
cons: chances of full time very slim

job_title: Student Success Specialist in Nixa, MO
pros: We were not without a job over the entire course of the pandemic.
cons: The salary amount given is not fair to many employees.

review_title: Working as a Writing Tutor in Carol Jones Writing Center
pros: This experience, more than anything else, prepared me to be a student and helped me develop critical thinking skills. It also put me in direct contact with writing/English professionals who went out of their way to help me develop professionally. I worked with some of the most motivated and (later) successful people I know. The Director develops maintains a work-culture conducive for his clients and stimulating for his team. Even if you're not a writing/English major, this job will help you make the most of all the soft-skill training your higher-education is suppose to provide you. Tutoring also gives you a since of helping out your community.  This isn't just a job; it's the ninth semester of college that's a cheaper investment in your education and yourself than Grad school.
cons: The pay can be prohibitory for anyone trying to earn enough to pay for college without loans. You'll never have full-time hours and there's no room for internal growth. Staff rotation occurs fairly often (a necessity for the job), and some of your colleagues aren't as mature as others.

review_title: Provides a needed service, not a great place to work
pros: It is an needed asset to the community. Most instructors I knew were extremely committed to their student, their mission, and the community.
cons: Waste, internal hiring irregularities, overreaching - this is a 2 year college, not a 4 year university. If you are cute, young and blonde, you will go far. Qualifications don't necessarily matter. I believe at one point in time it did, but not anymore. Peter Principal is alive and well here.

pros: Mission of the institution, services provided to students, dedicated faculty and staff
cons: Weak leadership who promote unprofessional behavior and immature tactics among employees (backstabbing, unhealthy competition, etc.), promotes unqualified cronies from within, makes decisions based on personalities and advancement of a select few instead of what's truly bets for enhancing student learning and success.

pros: The atmosphere of the school is very positive and the Department that I work in is more like an extended family in that everyone tries to help each other out. The senior staff is very good about nurturing younger/newer instructors and giving them guidance to help them find there way in their career. Another great thing is that when you are able to help a student attain their goals than you have helped to change someone else's life for the better.
cons: The maximum amount of hours that an adjunct can teach each semester is 9 credit hours. This makes it hard to raise a family when limits are set on your inability to work a full time job that you love.

job_title: Instructor -- Same Title for Everyone, No Academic Ranks in Springfield, MO
pros: Most of the long-term instructors I had contact with were there for (1) paid summers off and (2) great retirement plan.
cons: Atmosphere is very regimented. It's teaching by rote; no room for creativity or innovation. No opportunity for input into your own classes, your department or (heaven forbid) the school as a whole. The administration seemed to make a point of letting the faculty know they were expendable, and that we were at their mercy. There was no concern for work/life balance--I was actually told by one administrator that if they wanted to, they could set my teaching schedule to start at 6:30 a.m. and end at 11:00 p.m., and there would be "nothing you could do about it."

review_title: My experience started out strong, but has dimished over the semesters.
pros: Laid back office environment.  For the most part, professional staff and a close-knit group of faculty.  Smaller classes with more one-on-one attention with students.
cons: Some departments are now dictating everything from the order chapters are covered to how we grade.  Many faculty feel as if its no longer our own class, and that anyone off the street could step in and teach classes.  Oftentimes, faculty fail to be backed by those in power even when we follow policies set by the college.

pros: The departmental ethics that you are held too are refreshing as they leave little to no room for high school type cliques and difficulties.
cons: The culture of the campus as with many higher education campuses is one of constant scrutiny. Being in a setting where people are supposed to be adults only to find out that even the oldest of students can still surprise you and act like entitled children.

review_title: Best Place to Work While Taking Classes
pros: The staff is great and you feel like you are apart of a wonderful family. If you don't know how something needs to be done your managers are more than willing to help you both learn the concept and help you tutor the students.
cons: The only downside is that depending on where you are working in the lab there is sometimes nothing to do.

review_title: Most Unethical place I have ever worked!
pros: I am not sure what the pro's are to this establishment. The structure is crumbling and it is just a matter of time before all of the flaws of this college will appear in the news. HR is completely incompetent and has zero moral standards.
cons: Everything. There was a sexual harrassment case in our department HR swept it under the rug. Every issue that arises in this place is brushed aside. No policies are enforced. If you are a big wig at this college then you do not have any rules or regulations. Do not send your kids to this establishment. There are instructors that will sexually harrass your students and NOTHING will get done about it.

pros: I get to work with students that are attending college and trying to improve their lives.  I interact with people of all ages and backgrounds.  It is a very rewarding career!
cons: As a part-time instructor, you do not receive benefits.  It is somewhat difficult for you to make a significant amount of money working part-time just like any other job.

review_title: Fun place to work...if nothing else
pros: Insanely flexible hours, friendly co-workers, great managers, enjoyable work
cons: Laughable pay, even after years of working there. Communication can be lacking at times. Feels like part-timers are considered "lesser" than full time employees.

pros: Stable environment where people genuinely want to help others achieve their dreams. They make sound business decisions and senior leadership really care about the students, faculty, and staff.
cons: As with every culture you have those people who make it not enjoyable for the rest of the team. They are very few and far between. On average we have received less than stellar raises. This year will be 1%.

pros: I work with really talented people who are passionate about their jobs and care about students success. I am in a challenging roll and my skills are continually being developed. I am treated with respect and the atmosphere is great. My hours are flexible and I can work in any location.
cons: The number  of hour available are limited. The equipment definitely needs to be upgraded.

review_title: Leadership (starting at the top) is lacking.....
pros: Work/life balance, working around students.
cons: I had a question for my supervisor regarding an incident I witnessed while working, and he told me to not say anything. I then went to human resources and they "investigated" the incident, but did nothing to resolve it. My manager now treats me terrible. If you need leadership support, this employer will not give it to you so you may as well go find another job.

pros: OTC has been very good to adjunct faculty, staff.  Their policies are very respectful toward both staff and students.  They are a very service-oriented community.
cons: The credit hour limit was reduced in 2015 for adjuncts, which made it difficult to stay on as an adjunct professor. Otherwise, it was a great place to work.

pros: We have a very strong advising team and the community feels like a family.  OTC is open to new ideas and overall fun place to work.
cons: As with most colleges, we still operate under old systems that worked 50 years ago.

pros: nice atmosphere, people treat you well and seem helpful
cons: use adjuncts extensively.  Opportunity for full time teaching work is slim

review_title: One of the best places I've ever worked for!
pros: OTC has a community feel to it. Everyone is very helpful and pleasant to work with.  They encourage you to continue your education and work well with your schedule.
cons: The pay could be better.

pros: Great place to work. Coworkers are like family. Everyone is willing to help everyone else out if something is needed. Very student centered approach to teaching and working with students
cons: No cons that I can think of

pros: They always put the students first and they have great benefits! Even for PT employees!
cons: I have nothing to say for this section

job_title: Remote Sales Lead in Springfield, MO
pros: Flexibility, Book Discounts, Relateable Coworkers
cons: Hours, Employee Bias, Lack of Transparency

job_title: Bookstore Textbook Manager in Springfield, MO
pros: Great mission, great people to work with.
cons: Inter campus communication could be better.

job_title: MoWINs Project Director in Jefferson City, MO
pros: Love the small office atmosphere.
cons: There really are no cons.

pros: Flexible hours, great people, good opportunities to learn.
cons: Pay is low although benefits are good

pros: Flexible hours, learning environment, good hours
cons: Little room to progress due to small staff

pros: Wonderful work environment.  Focus on personal development.  Flexible schedule.
cons: You start at minimum wage.

pros: Great Culture. Great Benefits. Team Atmosphere.
cons: Pay is middle of the pack

pros: Nothing that I can think of
cons: They treat you like crap
